Heads Will Roll!!!
A note of explanation. The News-Letter sincerely
apologizes for any inconvenience caused by last Friday's
"shortage" of News-Letters. Apparently, some thugs took
offense at a particular sentence in an article and spirited
2000 copies away to their hideout. News of this heinous
deed reached our ears Saturday night. Naturally our
danders were stoked to new heights of outrage, but our
overwhelming concern was for the safety of the purloined
News-Letter. On Sunday we entered delicate negotiations
with intermediaries which assured us full return of the
stolen goods on Monday morning. Imagine our chagrin
when, upon examining the returned copies we saw an
obscenity stamped on what seemingly was the offending
passage.
Freedom of the press is one of the most precious liberties
we have in America; anyone who has suffered through a
high school civics course knows that. This transgression of
basic liberties ( plus the fact that our advertisers are giving
us hell) should not go unpunished. At this point, We have
passed the proverbial buck to higher authorities and
disciplinary action will be done.
The Maiyland Legislature just passed a new capital
punishment law. We hope this crime is covered in the new
judicial code.

It is fitting that one of the
few, elaborate rituals left at
Hopkins, Commemoration Day,

important part

anthropologist examines and so it

techniques developed by

examining our own immediate
environment, or, as Dr. Muller
fondly labeled it, the Hopkins
"family." I have taken some very
good Anthropology courses
here at Hopkins
and I have
learned that when examining a
ritual one of the many important
questions to ask is who or what is
being honored.
Many societies honor a deity
when they come together, which
we did perfunctorily by allowing
Dr. Wickwire to give a quick
Invocation. Many societies honor
the elder respected leaders of the
group, which we did with our
honorary degree for Levi-Strauss
and Chester Kerr and the
prominent, dignified showing of
our faculty in full academic
robes.Americans also seem to
enjoy honoring ideals, which we
did with our Ode to the School,
"the truth shall set you free,"
and our encouragement of
scholarship and wisdom. Yet Dr.
Muller's speech was also an
important part of our
Commemoration Day Ritual and
what he was holding up for our
respect and the object of our
honor was a balanced
budget.Muller took this occasion
to defend the University's "sad"
decision to close the School of
Health Services because of
economic difficulties. The
implication of Muller's speech
was that this University's prime
commitment is to having
large,readily accessible amounts
of money in hand in case it
should be needed. Perpetually
tanned, and looking very healthy,
Dr. Muller announed that
unfortunately) the School of
Health Services had to go. The
truth, though, is that the School
of Health Services in unique in its
commitment to primary health

care, and that its graduates are
performing necessary. services for
people who badly need them.

practitioners of primary health
care; physicians' assistants who

cannot find where they live,
doctors who graduate from the
financially solvent Johns Hopkins
School of Medicine.

Iran was awarded an honorary
degree and it was very obvious
that our Commemoration Day
Ritual honored financial support
for the University above all else.

Dr. Muller spoke. The truth may

Hopkins the truth, or our brand
of it, costs a great deal.

There are at least two ways of directing a play. The
first is to create a consistent, well-characterized
production and to present it to an audience for
entertainment and approval. The second method is to
direct a performance which will invariably please an
audience, while perhaps sacrificing character consistency
and the playwright's original conception. Laurlene Pratt,
director of Theatre Hopkins' current production of
Volpone, has taken the second route. The performance is
certainly entertaining and enjoyable for an audience. It
does not hold up under closer scrutiny.
Volpone is a milestone in the history of drama . It is the story of a man who , with the
aid of his servant , plays on the greed of his peers
to accrue a personal fortune . While it may be a
farce, it is a sophisticated, responsible farce. It tends
towards realism, has serious intent, and makes social
criticism. It is the director's duty to insure that the
production does not become irresponsible. That is, that
the didactic intent does not become tangled within a vine
of unbelievable events and characters, and thus removed
from the life of the play. The Theatre Hopkins
production, however, sacrifices serious content for the
sake of entertaining the audience. Not just occasionally,
as the superb script demands, but consistently, and at
times in violation of Ben Jonson's apparent intent.
Nosca, the "parasite," at one point enters, according to
the script, "wounded, bleeding." Mrs. Pratt has chosen to
ignore this bit of direction, and replaces the serious face
wound with a light kick in the derriere. (That it is a light
kick is without doubt, for if it were a hard kick the pain
Mosca feels would last longer than Mr. Basile's limp of
10-second durationwould indicate) This is entirely
inexcusable. Mosca has become caught in the process of
engineering the rape, by his master, pfa married woman.
This is a morally reprehensible crime. Indeed, it is
material better suited for tragedy than for farce. A
believable character of this time period would have
Wounded Mosca severely, and with great justification. By
altering the nature of the wound, Mrs. Pratt has altered
the nature of the farce. First, the didactic intent of the
wound is diluted into laughter. (The sight of blood on
stage generally stops laughter, at least temporarily)
Second, Bonario becomes less believable being the
Character who inflicts the wound on Mosca. The result is
that a responsible farce bcconies irresponsible.

To the Editor:
It is fitting that one of the
few, elaborate rituals left at
Hopkins, Commemoration Day,
featured as speaker Claude
Levi-Strauss, an anthropologist.
Rituals have always been an
important part
of what an
anthropologist examines and so it
is natural that we use those
techniques developed by
scientists such as Levi Strauss in
examining our own immediate
environment, or, as Dr. Muller
fondly labeled it, the Hopkins
"family." I have taken some very
good Anthropology courses
here at Hopkins
and I have
learned that when examining a
ritual one of the many important
questions to ask is who or what is
being honored.
Many societies honor a deity
when they come together, which
we did perfunctorily by allowing
Dr. Wickwire to give a quick
Invocation. Many societies honor
the elder respected leaders of the
group, which we did with our
honorary degree for Levi-Strauss
and Chester Kerr and the
prominent, dignified showing of
our faculty in full academic
robes.Americans also seem to
enjoy honoring ideals, which we
did with our Ode to the School,
"the truth shall set you free,"
and our encouragement of
scholarship and wisdom. Yet Dr.
Muller's speech was also an
important part of our
Commemoration Day Ritual and
what he was holding up for our
respect and the object of our
honor was a balanced
budget.Muller took this occasion
to defend the University's "sad"
decision to close the School of
Health Services because of
economic difficulties. The
implication of Muller's speech
was that this University's prime
commitment is to having
large,readily accessible amounts
of money in hand in case it
should be needed. Perpetually
tanned, and looking very healthy,
Dr. Muller announed that
unfortunately) the School of
Health Services had to go. The
truth, though, is that the School
of Health Services in unique in its
commitment to primary health

care, and that its graduates are
performing necessary. services for
people who badly need them.
The United States needs more
practitioners of primary health
care; physicians' assistants who
aid people who cannot afford, or
cannot find where they live,
doctors who graduate from the
financially solvent Johns Hopkins
School of Medicine.

Iran was awarded an honorary
degree and it was very obvious
that our Commemoration Day
Ritual honored financial support
for the University above all else.
It was less obvious this year, until
Dr. Muller spoke. The truth may
make you free, but at Johns
Hopkins the truth, or our brand
of it, costs a great deal.
Mary Waters
